_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This executive summary provides a brief overview of the Risk management Program (RMP) and the associated policies at the Stephenville Wastewater Treatment Plant (Stephenville WWTP), owned by the City of Stephenville and operated by Operations Management International, Inc. (OMI).  This executive summary also includes steps taken during the course of the five-year RMP update.

1.0  Prevention and Response Policies
OMI believes that it is important to provide a safe workplace to its emplyees and minimize the impact of its operations on the surrounding community and the environment.  Accordingly, OMI has develped proactive safety and environmental programs, which are reliant upon active emplyee participation and management leadership and support.  This same proactive philosophy was employed in the development and implementation of the Stephenville WWTP RMP for the chlorine system.  OMI has determined that the OSHA Process Safety Management standard also appliesto the personnel at the Stephenville WWTP and therefore has prepared this RMP to comply with the RMP Program 3 requirements.  By doing so, OMI affirms its proactive safety and environmental philosophy and acknowledges the inherent value of full RMP compliance.

The RMP prevention program is arguably the most important element of the rule.  Its program elements requireb the active participation of facility employees and management in conducting activities aimed at preventing accidental releases of regulated chemicals.  If prevention activities could be completely successful, there would be no need for emergency response activities, since no rekeases would occur.  Accordingly, a well developed and properly implemented prevention program will lower the possibility of an accidental release and minimize the consequences of a release should one occur.  OMI takes an active role in preventing accidental releases at all of the facilities it operates by ensuring that its employees are well-informed regarding the hazards as

sociated with the regulated processes (e.g. chlorine at the Stephenville WWTP) and actively participated in comprehensive process hazard analyses.  The employees that work on the chlorine system are properly trained in the safe operation of the covered processes and the safe handling of treatment chemicals.  They are aided in this work by complete, understandable system operating procedures.  

OMI management understands its duty to provide a safe working environment and to take measures to prevent accidents that may have an effect on the surrounding community.  This understanding is reflected in procedures described and referenced in the Stephenville WWTP RMP procedures and policies.  

As for emergency response, OMI has established and maintained procedures for emergemcy notification response.  This are reviewed with employees on a periodic basis and revised to accommodate changes in staffing when they occur.

2.0  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The Stephenville WWTP is located in Erath County, Texas.  The Stephenville WWTP treats wastewater through a series of physical and chemical treatment operations.  This wastewater treatment facility is an activated sludge, oxidation ditch aeration plant with both primary and secondary clarifiers.  The plant has an average design flow of 3.0 MGD.

The Stephenville WWTP utilizes chlorine as a biocide in the treatment of wastewater.  The chlorine is stored in one-ton containers with a maximum intended inventory of two containers (4,000 pounds) on site.  Therefore, the Stephenville WWTP is regulated under the RMP rule due to the volume of chlorine stored and used at the facility.

As required by the RMP regulation, OMI has updated the offsite consequence analysis and reported it to EPA using RMP*Submit 2004.

3.0  Prevention Steps for Chlorine
The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in the Stephenville WWTP RMP manual.  The prevention program includes the following eleme

nts:
3.1 Process safety information, which includes informationm pertaining to the hazards of chlorine in the process, process technology, and process equipment.  Process safety information was reviewed in June 2004.
3.2 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), which includes a systematic evaluation (by an emplyee team) of the hazards of the chlorine process, identification of previous process incidents, engineering and adminisrative controls, consequences of failure of the engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and possible safety and health effects of failure of controls.  PHA was revailidated in June 2004.
3.3 Operating Procedures, which include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.  The operating procedures were reviewed and updated in January 2006.
3.4 Training for each Stephenville WWTP employee involved in operating the chlorine system .  Most recent refresher training was provided to employees in January 2006.
3.5 Mechanical integrity procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of the chlorine process equipment.
3.6 Management of change procedures to manage changes (other than "replacements in kind") to the chlorine system.
3.7 Pre-startup safety reviewfor additions or significant modifications to the chlorine process, or any new regulated chemical processes.
3.8 Compliance audits at least every three years from 1999 to evaluate Stephenville WWTP RMP compliance.  The latest compliance audit was conducted in June 2004.
3.9 Incident investigation, to be conducted and documented for each incident that resulted in, or could have resonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of chlorine from the Stephenville WWTP.
3.10 Employee participation in the development and inplimentation of the Stephenville WWTP RMP, and employee access to RMP information.
3.11 Hot work prohibition on or near the chlorine system when chlorine is present in the affected section o

f the process.
3.12 Contractor management program, to ensure appropriate evaluation and selection of qualified contractors for work on or near the chlorine system, proper notification of contractors regarding known chlorine system hazards and the Stephenville WWTP emergency evacuation plan, limited access to the chlorine process and evaluation of contractor performance.  
N addition to these elements, the chlorine storage areaat the Stephenville WWTP is equipped with a chlorine leak detection device that continuously monitors the air for chlorine gas.  If the chlorine sensor detects a specified level, audio and visual alarms will be activated.  The alarm is routed to an automatic dialer, which calls the control room, project manager, the on-call operator.  The alarm system is maintained and tested on a regular basis to ensure proper operation should there be a chlorine release.  Management of Change procedures will be used for the upgrades to the chlorine system.

4.0 Accident History
Within the last five-year period, there have been no accidental releases of chlorine meeting the requirement of 40 CFR68.42.

5.0 Emergency Response Program
This facillity has established and maintains an emergency response program that is coordinated with local response agencies, including the Erath County Fire Department.  The program is described in detail in the Stephenville WWTP manual and meets the requirements of 40 CFR 68.95, which includes facillity notification of emergency responders and evacuation.  The goals of the program are to protect onsite employees from the hazardous effect of chemical releases and to minimize the effects of releases on the general public.  The program is routinely reviewed and updated to reflect personnel and regulatory changes.

6.0 Planned Changes for Improvement
Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought from employees.  Employee meetings that focus on safety issues are held regularly at the Stephenville WWTP.  Employees are encourag

ed and trained to recognize hazards and to present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequenses of those hazards.

As part of the RMP update to the Stephenville WWTP RMP program, process hazard were revalidated with key employees to meet the prevention program requirements.  As the equipment and the process has remained the same from the time the first process hazard anaysis was performed in 1999, the process hazard analysis conducted in June 2004 did not result in any new findidngs or recommendations.  The recommendations from the process hazard analysis in 1999, May of 2002 were reviewed for completion; a few recommendations are scheduled to be completed by September 2006.
